abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, highly likely sustainability, though modest
            institutional development impacts. Following are some
            factors that conditioned program implementation, and thus
            become important lessons for future operations. There is an
            urgent need for the Bank to monitor the economic and
            financial situation of Uruguay more closely. This was
            evident given both the 2000 Country Assistance Strategy
            (CAS), as well as the Bank work in the financial sector
            early in 2002, failed to perceive the risks threatening the
            Uruguayan economy, as a result of the financial crisis in
            Argentina, which hindered the initial preparation of the
            operation. Had the program been backed by stronger
            foundation within the CAS, and by the Bank's economic
            and sector work, there would have been greater information,
            and closeness with government officials, which no doubt
            would have led to an improved operation. Notwithstanding,
            actions implemented by the Bank team helped overcome some
            serious problems, such as the lack of a unified social
            policy authority in the country to act as a counterpart,
            forcing a program design and supervision at preparation with
            no Government support. As it happened, the Ministry of
            Economy was just a contact facilitator, with no power to
            develop the preparation of the program, particularly
            regarding social protection. Furthermore, there is need to
            maintain a dialogue with the Government on relevant
            structural reforms/policy actions with a long-term
            sustainable impact on the social sectors. A more consistent
            social development strategy would have helped design a more
            ambitious reform agenda. In retrospect, the project was
            effective given the seemingly medium and long term
            sustainable impact, in areas such as transparency,
            coherency, safety net, social information, and, monitoring
            and evaluation of the programs.

repnme.cdata!:
Uruguay - Structural Adjustment Loan (SAL)
            and Special Structural Adjustment Loan Project : release of
            the second tranche and waiver of two conditions

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Structural
            Adjustment Loan (SAL) and Special Structural Adjustment Loan
            (SSAL) at the time o f the acute banking and economic crisis
            in July 2002 were to contribute to fiscal adjustment, reform
            the National Mortgage Bank (BHU), protect social programs,
            improve the efficiency of social expenditures and reform the
            unemployment insurance regime. The program was part of a
            concerted effort with the International Monetary Fund (IMF)
            and the Inter-American Development Bank (IADB) to support
            Uruguay's efforts to withstand the impact o f strong
            external shocks, address domestic weaknesses and set the
            stage for sustainable growth over the medium and long term.
            As a result of tight fiscal, monetary and financial sector
            policies and reforms, Uruguay was able to reverse the
            downward trend in bank deposits, freely float its exchange
            rate without jeopardizing price stability, and reduce
            sovereign risk premia to manageable levels. After
            contracting sharply in 2002, the economy recovered in 2003
            and is projected to grow at least 9% in 2004. In view of the
            overall performance, progress with the implementation of the
            program as described in the Letter of Development Policy,
            and compliance with most of the specific conditions agreed
            in Schedule 3 to the Loan Agreements, the granting of two
            waivers (out of 18 conditions) as requested by the Borrower
            is recommended on a no-objection basis for release of the
            second tranche of the Loans 7137 and 7138. The basis for the
            evaluation of Borrower performance and the recommended
            waivers is set forth in this report.

repnme.cdata!:
Uruguay - Structural Adjustment Loan and
            Special Structural Adjustment Loan (SSAL) Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Loan (SAL) and
            Special Structural Adjustment Loan (SSAL) Projects are
            intended to help Ururguay withstand the large external
            shocks that have been affecting its economy over the past
            three years and to advance the Government's structural
            adjustment program. Policy conditionality covers fiscal and
            debt sustainability issues, including reduction in public
            expenditures, particularly the wage bill; increasing the tax
            on wages and pensions; and curtailing wage benefits in the
            public enterprises. It also covers reform of the public
            mortgage bank (BHU), including changing its organic chart to
            limit its lending activity to housing finance to individuals
            and only insofar as it can sell these mortgages to the
            private sector; allowing only deposits for "ahorro
            previo"; and prohibiting BHU to build; a thorough
            internal restructuring of the institution to fit its new
            functions; improving supervision of the public banks; and
            developing the market for mortgage-backed securities. policy
            conditionality also covers social protection measures,
            including developing a mechanism for cross-checking
            eligibility of beneficiaries of various social protection
            programs to enhance their efficiency and effectiveness;
            protection of social programs that attend poor children; and
            reform of the unemployment insurance system to improve its
            operation and expand its coverage. The loans will be carried
            out in close coordination with the IMF and the InterAmerican
            Development Bank.
